>>2365678
Mayors marathon is good. There's another one, I believe the Heart Run too. Those are the two main ones I remmeber.

As for things to do in Anchorage, some stuff off the top of my head:
- downtown has a couple decent things (historical sites, performing arts center, some actually decent restaurants (or hotdog stands if you want something cheap))
- standard drunk natives roaming the streets at all hours, but mostly later in the evening
- temperature will prolly be 60-75F or so, so pretty reasonable for walking/biking
- if you can, take the drive to Girdwood. It's like 45 minutes down the seward highway. There's a ski resort and hotel there, but it's also pretty in the summer. Lots of hiking there as well
- If you like road trips, renting a car and driving up to Fairbanks from Anchorage is like 6 or so hours, and you get to see a bunch of the state doing that. Road is also really good especially in summer
- If you like weed, there's places to purchase at like every street corner
- Anchorage is like small to medium sized US city. You'll find most things you'll find in any other city. I recommend either heading in Seward or Eagle River directions if you're seeking nature, animals, etc

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2365856
>how’s the bar scene in Anchorage? Any fun places to go to at night?
I think it's ok? anchorage is both a very car-friendly/necessary city and quite cold at night time, making leaving bars impractical without uber. Blue Line, Darwin's Theory, Chilkoot Charlie's all come to mind as far as decent bars.
>best places to go to for nature?
girdwood and the drive (seward highway), Hope has good camping in the summer, a lot of stuff north (Russian River campground comes to mind). If you like sea animals, there's a large "sealife" center in Seward. Seward is like a 3 hour drive past girdwood.
>is it true that it never gets dark in June?
The sun does set (and ride) year round in Anchorage. If you want to experience midnight sun, Fairbanks is probably your best bet. If you're feeling especially adventerous, Barrow (utqiagvik) at the top of alaska will def give you that experience.
>any good restaurants to try for authentic Alaskan food?
if im honest, i dont really know what authentic alaskan food is. whale? reindeer/caribou? moose? Whale and moose are fairly rare in anchorage, but you can definitely find reindeer and caribou meats at most non-chain restaurants. There's also specialty meat stores, Mr. Prime Beef, Alaska Sausage and Seafood come to mind. New Sagaya is a grocery store that carries a bunch of random game food. Rabbit, moose, caribou, whale (maybe??), etc.

as a side note, if you go out to the "beaches" in cook inlet, be very careful of the quicksand. that shit is no joke, and the water is cold as fuck. every year there's a bunch of tourists that fuck around in the sand and then have to have the fire department come out and rescue them.

Hopefully not a hard ask, but are there any aussie anons on this board that know much about interstate travel? Is there a general laundry list of things to be aware of?

Some specific questions:

If you go interstate by train, how long in advance should you book tickets?
Why do some flights between capitals cost less than some trains/ferries?
Are busses a better option than trains?
What occurs at interstate checkpoints and how much time is wasted at them?
If I work for cash/keep a lot of cash on me, how much money can I carry onto a plane before the people at the airport suspect I'm Pablo Escobar?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com: And can you use facebook marketplace or some website to couch surf as a cheaper alternative to hotels/airbnb?

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2366333

Not an expert (or avid train rider) but can answer some.

>If you go interstate by train, how long in advance should you book tickets?

They are not very busy, so I imagine you could probably book them at the station. I looked up one from brisbane to sydney and I could book the next one in 2 days.

>Why do some flights between capitals cost less than some trains/ferries?

Because planes are a much cheaper and faster alternative than trains for the large distances between Australian cities, why would you get 13hr train when you could get a 1hr 30min flight?

>Are busses a better option than trains?

Cheaper, but again 15-23hr trip vs 1hr 30min flight

>What occurs at interstate checkpoints and how much time is wasted at them?

As far as I know, generally there are no checkpoints (there was during covid), though in more rural areas they might check produce/animals.

>If I work for cash/keep a lot of cash on me, how much money can I carry onto a plane before the people at the airport suspect I'm Pablo Escobar?

No clue

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
In my experience you don't need to book far in advance. Might be different for something touristy in peak season, like the Ghan in winter.
Flights are heavily used in Australia so they just scale better. Only really applies if you book far enough in advance, plenty of over priced bullshit.
My personal preference is always trains but it just depends on where you're going, consider the price and duration of the trip.
There are no interstate check points, we're a federation. There was briefly checkpoints in place during Covid-19 restrictions but that's long over.
As far as I'm aware they don't check for this on domestic flights, but I guess if you take a briefcase full of 100 dollar notes they might ask questions.

threads.com:
This thread is dedicated to the discussion of airlines and major international airports.

I'm looking to go to Prague from the US this spring and my three main options are Lufthansa, KLM, and LOT. My assumption is that Lufthansa is the best but they all seem be equally mediocre according to the slew of tripadvisor reviews I've seen. So far I have flown internationally with United, American, EVA, British, Iberia, and ANA. So far EVA was the best in my opinion but I think I have bias due to the cutie flight attendants. All the American and European airlines seem to be on par with each other so should I just go with the cheapest? Right now, LOT is about $100 cheaper but something about them seems off. All advice and discussion is welcomed.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>LH, KLM, LOT
Yep, take the one that is the most convenient/cheapest.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
I went to Prague from the US twice this year. The first time was an American Airlines/British Air ticket and the second was Icelandair from US to London then British Air from London to Prague.

In my experience with international flights, the services are almost identical unless you pay significantly less or significantly more. Personally I prefer to go with the "top tier" airlines because I figure they have more money to put into maintenance and training, and they pay more for priority at airport gates so you don't have to sit on the tarmac as long.

On my first trip I got rerouted through Munich on Lufthansa and the service was great - they knew the flight was late so for the transfer in Munich they already had vans waiting to take people to their other flights as quickly as possible, didn't even go into the airport.

In the long run, $100-200 extra on a ticket is chump change and it's worth it to avoid stupid layovers or red eye flights or budget airlines etc. etc.

threads.name: Anonymous
threads.com:
The five ex-Soviet "Stans" aren't as much talked about as other destinations despite offering a lot to visitors.
I have lived and travelled through them, so let me give you an overview in case you're interested.

last_replies.name: Uzbekistan
last_replies.com:
In the "Big Three" cities of Samarkand/Bukhara/Khiva you will find the closes to mass tourism, with European boomers spending their retirement money on souvenirs to bring back to their boomer friends.
Still, it's nowhere near the levels of any European tourist city, even at the most popular sites you can just wait five minutes and you'll be only be sharing it with domestic tourists and local touts.

While the Big Three are what draw the most people, on a longer visit you may want to check out more nature-based destinations such as Karakalpakstan, site of what used to be the Aral Sea or the Fergana Valley where the above-mentiond souvenirs are actually made.

Moving between regions can be done by train or by domestic flight via Tashkent.
While the flights are comfortable and not too expensive, you can save money and experience authentic Uzbekistan by taking an overnight train, especially if you book third class (platzkart). If you find out that the experience is too authentic for you, you can easily bribe the conductor to find you a private compartment for about 10 to 15 dollars.

While Tashkent might be your entry point, you will quickly find out that it's a fairly boring city, especially the nightlife when compared to Almaty and Bishkek.
Sadly for the inclined tourist there are less and less Soviet-era buildings left untouched in Tashkent, but a simple trip to any neighbouring country will satisfy your cravings.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
What you definitely need are some skills reading Cyrillic, even in countries that formally switched to Roman characters.
With only English you won't get as far somebody who speaks just even basic Russian, English services are generally available but come at a premium.
Just using some basic greetings in the respective local languages will usually be met with enthusiasm, even if you then continue in Russian or pidgin English-Russian.

Kazakhstan and Kyrgyzstan are the two countries where you won't stand out as a white Westerner due to the high number of ethnic Russians, even at bazars you will get the same treatment as locals, at least until you open your mouth. Usually, this will work to your advantage, but be prepared to be talked to in Rapid Russian.

The region has a reputation of being dangerous, mostly due to the proximity to Afghanistan, but as a tourist the biggest risk you'll face is road traffic, some taxi rides will make even the most euphoric atheist pray for a safe journey.

In most cities you can save yourself a lot of trouble by installing the Yandex Taxi app, the local equivalent to Uber. Even just showing the app prices will give you stronger hand while haggling, never use a metered taxi without fixating a price first, it's an invitation to get ripped off.

Tourist SIM cards are available in every country, the easiest being in Kyrgyzstan where they'll just hand them out for free at busy border crossings, the most expensive being in Turkmenistan (and you may not be able to use shitpost on /int/), see the ever-useful Prepaid SIM Card Wiki for more details.

The best English internet site for this region is Caravanistan, some of the articles may become outdated but the forum will usually have the relevant updates.
I'll check this thread for questions and try to answer until this thread dies, so ask away!

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2361825
Anon, rather than give you the fish for once, i'll teach you how to fish :

ask yourself if you can get a decent paying job with a high school degree at home to start with, then ask yourself if that job would be easy to get abroad, i.e ask yourself the following :

>Is it a remote job ? If so, am I willing to visa run and work abroad while pretending i'm a tourist on a constant visa run while getting fucked over with foreign exchange rates whenever i'm withdrawing money ?
>Is it a job many locals can do ? e.g engineering in china or food service in vietnam ?
>if it is, what do I bring to the table ? (years of experience, niche specialization such as french cuisine to keep with the food service example)
>can I apply a "white worship" bonus to the job i'm doing ? (applies only if you're white and it's a service oriented job such as teaching or selling shit)
>Are there many locals that can compete with me knowing all these factors ?
>Do you have money ? (very important if you want to get your own company there)
>Do you have a bachelor's degree ?(very important for many countries that require it for a work visa)

If you've answered "yes", "no" and "no" to the last three questions, an expatriation is nigh impossible. Consider working holiday visas if possible. If not and you're from an anglo country, a TEFL certification and teaching english is pretty much the only way to go. Some countries ask for a bach, some don't. good luck.

>>2365790
(3/3)
I’m not into brazilian food. The only thing I can think of as a meal would be feijoada for you to try. You will feel full for next day though. But you should try some rodizio (all you can eat; we have pizza, meat (churrascaria) and japanese food rodizios), some buffet restaurant (quilo) where you pay for the kg of food you put in your plate, some boteco (bar) foods and padaria (bakery).
Bakeries in São Paulo are huge part of our daily life. Whether for buying just some bread and cold cuts to take home, grabbing a coffee, or having breakfast or lunch/dinner. Some even have buffets, sushi bars and pizza ovens.
In bakeries and boteco you should try things like pastel, coxinha, bolinho de bacalhau (it’s actually portuguese) and other of those deep fried finger foods. Brigadeiro is a traditional dessert here. It may be too sweet for you but it’s worth trying.

>>2361870
After university I went a year to Japan for an internship job. Being German, another European country would have been boring probably. Not wanted to get shot so US was out too. Japan is a country that is very different to everything I knew and not a place I would probably end up later in life except for holiday. So I went there. Great experience, best time in my life and I don't even like anime. There is so much to do and see, it never gets boring, not one day. It's a bit tricky to make friends because Japanese are shy and reserved and often don't speak english. But since I worked at a company full of people my age I could do a lot with them after work. And it's so easy there, I haven't cooked once because there is endless amount of restaurants that serve you quick, affordable and very delicious food. I always did night walks after work which is very relaxing, i miss this the most. Also karaoke, izakaya, hiking in pure nature, finding movie locations of old samurai movies, museums, lots of bars, gaijin hunter, car meet ups, etc. Nightclubs aren't as good as in Europe though and mostly filled with shady Japanese men and gaijin. I would say only 10% girls.

Only bad thing about it: 10 years passed already but I still constantly compare everything with Japan now. If the train here is late (as most of the time) I think "why the hell is every train in japan punctual and why do I live in a third world shithole". It can get a bit depressing sometimes.

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2363061
Simply put OP, you have to think of Asia as a kind of spectrum of cultures and wealthiness. If you want your trip to be interesting as a beginner, you'd be well inspired to visit the extremes first, and the more nuanced countries later. China and Japan for example have two very different cultures whereas Korea and Taiwan are a nuance of the former.
Vietnam and Thailand are the bigger cultural and economic actors of the ex-indochina region and thus visiting laos and cambodia would just be a waste of time for now.
The three outliers are the philippines (due to it being simply unique), and Indonesia/malaysia (visiting one of em is enough, the other one's basically the same). If you're planning to do a long trip with multiple countries, you should definitely do both in one swing, like say Japan and Vietnam or China and Thailand. Or Japan and Thailand, since China hasn't opened yet.

I also suggest you start with the poorer country first, since third world countries have some inconveniences i'm sure you'll figure out, and by going to the more developed country after that it'll allow your body and mind to take a break from the hustle and bustle. This being said, it all hinges on how much time you have. If 2 weeks is all you have you can honestly just stay in Japan for the duration of the trip. You'd save more money that way to do more interesting stuff.

threads.com:
So I'm thinking of leaving tomorrow and trek through my country, Tanzania. Any advice on cross-country walking? I'll leave my phone and everything behind. Carry a backpack and a few clothes and some things to lie on and cover myself, a container for food I buy along the way, and a 2 Litre bottle of water. I'll post a don't worry message on Twitter, and have about $2000 in my bank account(which is a lot in Tanzania) and will be withdrawing little by little at ATMs.

Why am I doing this? After my last suicide attempt life has been feeling pointless. I dropped out of university and have been blaming myself for not making the suicide work. I always believe the universe is so big, you can choose to minimize your gaze and focus on the little you can control, or expand your horizons and explore. I've done the former for so long and it hasn't left me satisfied, might as well try the latter for a change. I hope in this journey I find a reason to live, or a reason not to, but regardless, I owe myself to try.

I'm currently in Bukoba(picrel), I'm thinking of following the paved trunk roads and sleeping alongside it all the way to Dar es salaam. I'll try to stay at most 2 days without food before I consider taking a small bus to the closest town.

Anyway. Any advice on cross-country walking?

I know Madrid has been mentioned already, but Barcelona is by FAR my favourite city in the world to stay in, especially long term. I'm eventually planning on moving there.

For me, Barcelona is the perfect mix of a big, industrial modern cosmopolitan city, with beautiful historic architecture and a refreshing combination of both chilled out beach/party/tourist elements and normal every-day working life.

Madrid is very similar, except a more conservative, more administrative city with far less touristic/party elements. For me, I could explore Barcelona for several weeks, seeing new parts of the city, meeting people from all over the world, visiting interesting museums, relaxing at different beaches and eating at different types of restaurants and not get bored. I could probably only do the same in Madrid for several days.

Honestly, I don't have a single negative thing to say about Barcelona.

I didn't do the Peace Corps, but two of my close friend did. One went to Moldova for a community development position, and the other was sent to sub-Saharan Africa as a teacher. Neither had an education degree. However, I think both had limited teaching experience, as they had volunteered at a refugee education center in our hometown.

Unless something has changed in the past several years, you should still be eligible for most teaching positions. This is what most volunteers do, unless they have outstanding experience or skills in other fields. you like or dislike anything in particular? weather, food, nightlife, multiculturalism, architecture

im a boring boomer, i like walking around in a comfy area, eating some nice food, i do some sightseeing if there aren't long lines.

last_replies.com:
I agree with the poster above that it’s hard to offer suggestions without knowing what you like to do, or where you’ve already been.

But from where I am (an Easyjet hub, among other things), I have enjoyed very quick, very cheap trips to cities including but not limited to Paris, Barcelona, Budapest, Sevilla, a couple of cities in Sicily, Istanbul (although this one deserves more than a weekend and may be a long flight depending on where you begin), Lisbon, Athens, Skopje, Malta, a couple of Bulgarian cities, Ljubljana, Zagreb, and Prishtina. A handful of additional post-socialist dumps, too, but I like that kind of place; you may not.

Speaking of ex-Yugo, I’ve never made it to Dubrovnik or Split; they both look cool but intolerably crowded in the summer, so perhaps now would be a good time to go.

Oh, and tickets to Tel Aviv are really cheap at the moment (less than €100 round trip from where I am), and my kids’ pediatrician insists that it’s great for tourists. But I don’t know if it’s even open at the moment.

lolno, that's not omaha. There is literally nothing in Elkhorn besides a high school, homes and a golf course. West Omaha is essentially richfag suburbia, Elkhorn is a few streets surrounded by farmland. You can expect more of your small town living like in Maine. You can expect to have no uber there either since you're so far out west everyone there has a car. It's not as small as Camden and its literal 5 streets but Camden has more soul.
>any tips?
Move to downtown, midtown/blackstone or aksarben. Avoid north omaha (nogs) and enter south omaha at your own risk (hispandex). Rent is cheap if you want your own place in the city proper. If you want a house then move to bellevue. People are nice but be prepared to essentially spend time eating, drinking, watching sports and a few clubs for dancing.

Spots to check out:
>Old Market/Downtown Cocktail Bars
Berry & Rye, Wicked Rabbit, Mercury, Green Room, Laka Lono's Rum Club, Anna's Place
>Dive bars
Rose & Crown Pub, Billy Frogs, Alderman's, Down Under Lounge (sometimes has live music, check their fb page)
>Clubs
Beer Can Alley @ Capitol District (Country/Rap, 2 sections), Bar 415 (EDM), Throwback Lounge
>Music
The Jewell (jazz), Slowdown (typically rock), Reverb Lounge, Holland Perf. Arts Center
>Casinos
Go to Horseshoe in Iowa right across the river.
>Bars in Blackstone/Midtown
Nite Owl, Little Ricky's Blackstone Social, Sullivan's Bar, Red Lion Lounge, Crescent Moon (beer hall), Proof (whiskey bar)
>aksarben
stick to stinson park and 67th street for the better spots but the area is nice, close to an all girls college too so good spot to find a girl to socialize with

last_replies.name: Anonymous
last_replies.com:
>>2364754 (cont.)
Restaurants to check out:
Dirty Birds for the fried chicken, Block 16 for burgers, La Buvette for a european style french restaurant with a good wine selection, Le Bouillon for a better but pricier french place, Gather in Omaha for fusion, IkaSan for ramen, Mula and Hook & Lime for mexican, Planck Seafood for seafood, Hiro88 or Blue Fin Sake for sushi (hiro has a great happy hour tho), Via Farina for Italian, Stirnella for american food. I hear Bombay is great for Indian in Aksarben, but most asian food sucks here (which is odd given the asian market is insanely versatile).

Little Bohemia is a nice walk and has a few good spots like Tiny House Bar and Fizzy's Fountain & Liquors. The zoo is huge and a good way to kill a day. The Lauritzen Gardens are great in december once the lights go up. The riverfront mall was just redone last summer and it's a nice park.

The best 2 bars closest to you will be Barnato at the Bentley dealership and Alice a bit south. If you like cigars go to Safari and ignore Havana Garage entirely. You can try hiking in fontanelle forest but there's really not much for /out/fags. Oh we also have 88 Tactical for guns, the dudes who caused national cope and sneed for MUH FAR RIGHT DOGWHISTLES.

There's a lot of small events happening in town. Event Vesta is a decent app to see local offerings. There's a lot of local breweries as well if you want stuff to check out. You'll have to search if you want to find good stuff but a few gems exist here and there.
